🇦🇪 Dubai Real Estate is on Fire 🔥 Q1 has just wrapped, and the numbers are speaking loud and clear: Dubai continues to be one of the strongest real estate markets globally — and it’s not slowing down.Here’s a quick breakdown you need to see:💰 AED 142.57 Billion in Property SalesThat’s a 30.3% increase YoY compared to Q1 2024 with a total of 45,381 properties :Apartments : 44% of total sales ( +12.9% vs Q1 2024 )Villas : 33% ( + 55.1% vs Q1 2024 )Land : 21% ( 123.5% vs Q1 2024 ) Commercial : 2% ( +25.3% vs Q1 2024 ) 🏡 Massive Growth in Villas & LandVillas: +55.1%Land: +123.5%Prime communities and waterfront plots are leading the charge — demand is red-hot.📍 Top Performing AreasVillas: Wadi Al Safa 5, Al Yufrah 1, Madinat Al MataarApartments: Business Bay, JVC, Burj KhalifaLand: Palm Jabal Ali, Al Yelayiss 1These zones are seeing unmatched movement — both for end-users and savvy investors.📈 Secondary Market Surging+36.4% YoY in valueThis is a strong signal: people trust completed assets, and liquidity is high.🏦 Mortgages Rising in VolumeAED 41.02B in mortgages with a 27% jump in number of transactions Financing is becoming more accessible — even for premium assets.🎁 Gifting Real Estate — A Dubai SpecialtyAED 9.63B worth of properties were gifted — a unique trend showing legacy planning and generational wealth, especially in Palm Jumeirah and Emirates Living.💎 Luxury is BoomingSome of Q1’s standout deals:AED 140M — Dubai Hills EstateAED 130M — Sobha Hartland 2AED 115M — Palm Jumeirah📊What It MeansDubai is not just about lifestyle anymore — it’s a global value play.With world-class infrastructure, smart regulation, and unmatched ROI potential,now is the time to make your move. 🔑 At SAB Capital, we’re helping investors make strategic decisions — tailored to short-term gains or long-term legacy. If you’re serious about investing in Dubai, let’s connect. We’ve got the data, the access, and the local insight.hashtag#DubaiRealEstate hashtag#InvestmentOpportunity hashtag#Q12025 hashtag#LuxuryLiving hashtag#SABCapital hashtag#DubaiProperty hashtag#UAEPropertyMarket hashtag#Villas hashtag#LandInvestments hashtag#DubaiInvestments hashtag#PropertyTrends

🇦🇪 Dubai Real Estate is on Fire 🔥 Q1 has just wrapped, and the numbers are speaking loud and clear: Dubai continues to be one of the strongest real estate markets globally — and it’s not slowing down.Here’s a quick breakdown you need to see:💰 AED 142.57 Billion in Property SalesThat’s a 30.3% increase YoY compared to Q1 2024 with a total of 45,381 properties :Apartments : 44% of total sales ( +12.9% vs Q1 2024 )Villas : 33% ( + 55.1% vs Q1 2024 )Land : 21% ( 123.5% vs Q1 2024 ) Commercial : 2% ( +25.3% vs Q1 2024 ) 🏡 Massive Growth in Villas & LandVillas: +55.1%Land: +123.5%Prime communities and waterfront plots are leading the charge — demand is red-hot.📍 Top Performing AreasVillas: Wadi Al Safa 5, Al Yufrah 1, Madinat Al MataarApartments: Business Bay, JVC, Burj KhalifaLand: Palm Jabal Ali, Al Yelayiss 1These zones are seeing unmatched movement — both for end-users and savvy investors.📈 Secondary Market Surging+36.4% YoY in valueThis is a strong signal: people trust completed assets, and liquidity is high.🏦 Mortgages Rising in VolumeAED 41.02B in mortgages with a 27% jump in number of transactions Financing is becoming more accessible — even for premium assets.🎁 Gifting Real Estate — A Dubai SpecialtyAED 9.63B worth of properties were gifted — a unique trend showing legacy planning and generational wealth, especially in Palm Jumeirah and Emirates Living.💎 Luxury is BoomingSome of Q1’s standout deals:AED 140M — Dubai Hills EstateAED 130M — Sobha Hartland 2AED 115M — Palm Jumeirah📊What It MeansDubai is not just about lifestyle anymore — it’s a global value play.With world-class infrastructure, smart regulation, and unmatched ROI potential,now is the time to make your move. 🔑 At SAB Capital, we’re helping investors make strategic decisions — tailored to short-term gains or long-term legacy. If you’re serious about investing in Dubai, let’s connect. We’ve got the data, the access, and the local insight.hashtag#DubaiRealEstate hashtag#InvestmentOpportunity hashtag#Q12025 hashtag#LuxuryLiving hashtag#SABCapital hashtag#DubaiProperty hashtag#UAEPropertyMarket hashtag#Villas hashtag#LandInvestments hashtag#DubaiInvestments hashtag#PropertyTrends

Missed out on the Valley?The first objection I use to hear when talking about this project is: it’s so far out!Is it really? Let’s clarify - yes it’s in kilometres further then other areas when measured to downtown, but is it longer? No! usually the time till destination is shorter due to no traffic and a wider highway.Jumeirah golf estate to Downtown Dubai Mall 26km and 40 minutes (light traffic)The Valley to downtown 26km and 30 minutes!Now’s the Chance to get a Villa in the best location The Valley has to offer! Surrounded by parks and a flowing wadi.EMAAR has proven itself once again that they deserve to be called a master community developer. Families and investors have recognised this area as the place to live, outside the buzzing noise of the city and with low initial investment achieving high rental yields.Not too far out anymore? Drop me a message and thank me later ✨

🇦🇪 Dubai Real Estate is on Fire 🔥 Q1 has just wrapped, and the numbers are speaking loud and clear: Dubai continues to be one of the strongest real estate markets globally — and it’s not slowing down.Here’s a quick breakdown you need to see:💰 AED 142.57 Billion in Property SalesThat’s a 30.3% increase YoY compared to Q1 2024 with a total of 45,381 properties :Apartments : 44% of total sales ( +12.9% vs Q1 2024 )Villas : 33% ( + 55.1% vs Q1 2024 )Land : 21% ( 123.5% vs Q1 2024 ) Commercial : 2% ( +25.3% vs Q1 2024 ) 🏡 Massive Growth in Villas & LandVillas: +55.1%Land: +123.5%Prime communities and waterfront plots are leading the charge — demand is red-hot.📍 Top Performing AreasVillas: Wadi Al Safa 5, Al Yufrah 1, Madinat Al MataarApartments: Business Bay, JVC, Burj KhalifaLand: Palm Jabal Ali, Al Yelayiss 1These zones are seeing unmatched movement — both for end-users and savvy investors.📈 Secondary Market Surging+36.4% YoY in valueThis is a strong signal: people trust completed assets, and liquidity is high.🏦 Mortgages Rising in VolumeAED 41.02B in mortgages with a 27% jump in number of transactions Financing is becoming more accessible — even for premium assets.🎁 Gifting Real Estate — A Dubai SpecialtyAED 9.63B worth of properties were gifted — a unique trend showing legacy planning and generational wealth, especially in Palm Jumeirah and Emirates Living.💎 Luxury is BoomingSome of Q1’s standout deals:AED 140M — Dubai Hills EstateAED 130M — Sobha Hartland 2AED 115M — Palm Jumeirah📊What It MeansDubai is not just about lifestyle anymore — it’s a global value play.With world-class infrastructure, smart regulation, and unmatched ROI potential,now is the time to make your move. 🔑 At SAB Capital, we’re helping investors make strategic decisions — tailored to short-term gains or long-term legacy. 🚀 A game-changing moment for digital identity — and it starts with ownership.nmbr, Inc., the Dubai-based startup founded by Ahmad Takatkah (أحمد طقاطقه) and officially registered in Delaware, has just opened its public waitlist as of April 14. But this isn’t just another product launch — it’s a movement.The first 1 million users will receive exclusive “nmbrs” — digital identifiers that double as encrypted, user-owned IDs — plus Restricted Common Stock, giving each user real equity in the company.🔐 The mission? Reinvent the phone number into a secure, private, and globally recognized digital identity, fully owned by the individual — not by corporations.This is more than tech. It’s a new communication infrastructure built on privacy, community, and shared ownership.💬 “We’re not just building a service — we’re building an ecosystem where users are partners,” says founder Ahmad Takatkah.hashtag#nmbr hashtag#DigitalIdentity hashtag#StartupVision hashtag#PrivacyTech hashtag#EquityForUsers hashtag#DubaiStartups hashtag#TechInnovation hashtag#FutureOfCommunication https://lnkd.in/gbi5tD8Q

🇦🇪 Dubai Real Estate is on Fire 🔥 Q1 has just wrapped, and the numbers are speaking loud and clear: Dubai continues to be one of the strongest real estate markets globally — and it’s not slowing down.Here’s a quick breakdown you need to see:💰 AED 142.57 Billion in Property SalesThat’s a 30.3% increase YoY compared to Q1 2024 with a total of 45,381 properties :Apartments : 44% of total sales ( +12.9% vs Q1 2024 )Villas : 33% ( + 55.1% vs Q1 2024 )Land : 21% ( 123.5% vs Q1 2024 ) Commercial : 2% ( +25.3% vs Q1 2024 ) 🏡 Massive Growth in Villas & LandVillas: +55.1%Land: +123.5%Prime communities and waterfront plots are leading the charge — demand is red-hot.📍 Top Performing AreasVillas: Wadi Al Safa 5, Al Yufrah 1, Madinat Al MataarApartments: Business Bay, JVC, Burj KhalifaLand: Palm Jabal Ali, Al Yelayiss 1These zones are seeing unmatched movement — both for end-users and savvy investors.📈 Secondary Market Surging+36.4% YoY in valueThis is a strong signal: people trust completed assets, and liquidity is high.🏦 Mortgages Rising in VolumeAED 41.02B in mortgages with a 27% jump in number of transactions Financing is becoming more accessible — even for premium assets.🎁 Gifting Real Estate — A Dubai SpecialtyAED 9.63B worth of properties were gifted — a unique trend showing legacy planning and generational wealth, especially in Palm Jumeirah and Emirates Living.💎 Luxury is BoomingSome of Q1’s standout deals:AED 140M — Dubai Hills EstateAED 130M — Sobha Hartland 2AED 115M — Palm Jumeirah📊What It MeansDubai is not just about lifestyle anymore — it’s a global value play.With world-class infrastructure, smart regulation, and unmatched ROI potential,now is the time to make your move. 🔑 At SAB Capital, we’re helping investors make strategic decisions — tailored to short-term gains or long-term legacy. If you’re serious about investing in Dubai, let’s connect. The UAE Ministry of Finance has issued Cabinet Decision No. 84 of 2025, which provides further clarification on the requirements for preparing audited financial statements under the Corporate Tax Law. This new decision replaces Cabinet Decision No. 82 of 2023 and will apply to tax periods beginning on or after 1 January 2025.https://lnkd.in/g6Gawn3J A key update introduced by the new decision is that Tax Groups are now obligated to prepare and maintain special purpose audited financial statements in line with the format, procedures, and rules prescribed by the Federal Tax Authority (FTA).Notably, Clause 3 of Article 2 introduces an unexpected and intriguing provision: Qualifying Free Zone Persons engaged in the distribution of goods or materials in or from a Designated Zone, in accordance with Cabinet Decision No. 265 of 2023, must comply with any additional procedures set by the FTA. The inclusion of this clause - within a decision focused primarily on financial statement requirements - hints that the FTA may be preparing to issue specific compliance obligations targeting Designated Zone distributors.hashtag#CorporateTax hashtag#TaxAdvisory hashtag#QFZP

🚀 A game-changing moment for digital identity — and it starts with ownership.nmbr, Inc., the Dubai-based startup founded by Ahmad Takatkah (أحمد طقاطقه) and officially registered in Delaware, has just opened its public waitlist as of April 14. But this isn’t just another product launch — it’s a movement.The first 1 million users will receive exclusive “nmbrs” — digital identifiers that double as encrypted, user-owned IDs — plus Restricted Common Stock, giving each user real equity in the company.🔐 The mission? Reinvent the phone number into a secure, private, and globally recognized digital identity, fully owned by the individual — not by corporations.This is more than tech. It’s a new communication infrastructure built on privacy, community, and shared ownership.💬 “We’re not just building a service — we’re building an ecosystem where users are partners,” says founder Ahmad Takatkah.hashtag#nmbr hashtag#DigitalIdentity hashtag#StartupVision hashtag#PrivacyTech hashtag#EquityForUsers hashtag#DubaiStartups hashtag#TechInnovation hashtag#FutureOfCommunication https://lnkd.in/gbi5tD8Q

🇦🇪 Dubai Real Estate is on Fire 🔥 Q1 has just wrapped, and the numbers are speaking loud and clear: Dubai continues to be one of the strongest real estate markets globally — and it’s not slowing down.Here’s a quick breakdown you need to see:💰 AED 142.57 Billion in Property SalesThat’s a 30.3% increase YoY compared to Q1 2024 with a total of 45,381 properties :Apartments : 44% of total sales ( +12.9% vs Q1 2024 )Villas : 33% ( + 55.1% vs Q1 2024 )Land : 21% ( 123.5% vs Q1 2024 ) Commercial : 2% ( +25.3% vs Q1 2024 ) 🏡 Massive Growth in Villas & LandVillas: +55.1%Land: +123.5%Prime communities and waterfront plots are leading the charge — demand is red-hot.📍 Top Performing AreasVillas: Wadi Al Safa 5, Al Yufrah 1, Madinat Al MataarApartments: Business Bay, JVC, Burj KhalifaLand: Palm Jabal Ali, Al Yelayiss 1These zones are seeing unmatched movement — both for end-users and savvy investors.📈 Secondary Market Surging+36.4% YoY in valueThis is a strong signal: people trust completed assets, and liquidity is high.🏦 Mortgages Rising in VolumeAED 41.02B in mortgages with a 27% jump in number of transactions Financing is becoming more accessible — even for premium assets.🎁 Gifting Real Estate — A Dubai SpecialtyAED 9.63B worth of properties were gifted — a unique trend showing legacy planning and generational wealth, especially in Palm Jumeirah and Emirates Living.💎 Luxury is BoomingSome of Q1’s standout deals:AED 140M — Dubai Hills EstateAED 130M — Sobha Hartland 2AED 115M — Palm Jumeirah📊What It MeansDubai is not just about lifestyle anymore — it’s a global value play.With world-class infrastructure, smart regulation, and unmatched ROI potential,now is the time to make your move. 🔑 At SAB Capital, we’re helping investors make strategic decisions — tailored to short-term gains or long-term legacy. If you’re serious about investing in Dubai, let’s connect. 🚀 A game-changing moment for digital identity — and it starts with ownership.nmbr, Inc., the Dubai-based startup founded by Ahmad Takatkah (أحمد طقاطقه) and officially registered in Delaware, has just opened its public waitlist as of April 14. But this isn’t just another product launch — it’s a movement.The first 1 million users will receive exclusive “nmbrs” — digital identifiers that double as encrypted, user-owned IDs — plus Restricted Common Stock, giving each user real equity in the company.🔐 The mission? Reinvent the phone number into a secure, private, and globally recognized digital identity, fully owned by the individual — not by corporations.This is more than tech. It’s a new communication infrastructure built on privacy, community, and shared ownership.💬 “We’re not just building a service — we’re building an ecosystem where users are partners,” says founder Ahmad Takatkah.hashtag#nmbr hashtag#DigitalIdentity hashtag#StartupVision hashtag#PrivacyTech hashtag#EquityForUsers hashtag#DubaiStartups hashtag#TechInnovation hashtag#FutureOfCommunication https://lnkd.in/gbi5tD8Q

The UAE Ministry of Finance has issued Cabinet Decision No. 84 of 2025, which provides further clarification on the requirements for preparing audited financial statements under the Corporate Tax Law. This new decision replaces Cabinet Decision No. 82 of 2023 and will apply to tax periods beginning on or after 1 January 2025.https://lnkd.in/g6Gawn3J A key update introduced by the new decision is that Tax Groups are now obligated to prepare and maintain special purpose audited financial statements in line with the format, procedures, and rules prescribed by the Federal Tax Authority (FTA).Notably, Clause 3 of Article 2 introduces an unexpected and intriguing provision: Qualifying Free Zone Persons engaged in the distribution of goods or materials in or from a Designated Zone, in accordance with Cabinet Decision No. 265 of 2023, must comply with any additional procedures set by the FTA. The inclusion of this clause - within a decision focused primarily on financial statement requirements - hints that the FTA may be preparing to issue specific compliance obligations targeting Designated Zone distributors.hashtag#CorporateTax hashtag#TaxAdvisory hashtag#QFZP

The UAE Ministry of Finance has issued Cabinet Decision No. 84 of 2025, which provides further clarification on the requirements for preparing audited financial statements under the Corporate Tax Law. This new decision replaces Cabinet Decision No. 82 of 2023 and will apply to tax periods beginning on or after 1 January 2025.https://lnkd.in/g6Gawn3J A key update introduced by the new decision is that Tax Groups are now obligated to prepare and maintain special purpose audited financial statements in line with the format, procedures, and rules prescribed by the Federal Tax Authority (FTA).Notably, Clause 3 of Article 2 introduces an unexpected and intriguing provision: Qualifying Free Zone Persons engaged in the distribution of goods or materials in or from a Designated Zone, in accordance with Cabinet Decision No. 265 of 2023, must comply with any additional procedures set by the FTA. The inclusion of this clause - within a decision focused primarily on financial statement requirements - hints that the FTA may be preparing to issue specific compliance obligations targeting Designated Zone distributors.hashtag#CorporateTax hashtag#TaxAdvisory hashtag#QFZP

🚀 A game-changing moment for digital identity — and it starts with ownership.nmbr, Inc., the Dubai-based startup founded by Ahmad Takatkah (أحمد طقاطقه) and officially registered in Delaware, has just opened its public waitlist as of April 14. But this isn’t just another product launch — it’s a movement.The first 1 million users will receive exclusive “nmbrs” — digital identifiers that double as encrypted, user-owned IDs — plus Restricted Common Stock, giving each user real equity in the company.🔐 The mission? Reinvent the phone number into a secure, private, and globally recognized digital identity, fully owned by the individual — not by corporations.This is more than tech. It’s a new communication infrastructure built on privacy, community, and shared ownership.💬 “We’re not just building a service — we’re building an ecosystem where users are partners,” says founder Ahmad Takatkah.hashtag#nmbr hashtag#DigitalIdentity hashtag#StartupVision hashtag#PrivacyTech hashtag#EquityForUsers hashtag#DubaiStartups hashtag#TechInnovation hashtag#FutureOfCommunication https://lnkd.in/gbi5tD8Q

The UAE Ministry of Finance has issued Cabinet Decision No. 84 of 2025, which provides further clarification on the requirements for preparing audited financial statements under the Corporate Tax Law. This new decision replaces Cabinet Decision No. 82 of 2023 and will apply to tax periods beginning on or after 1 January 2025.https://lnkd.in/g6Gawn3J A key update introduced by the new decision is that Tax Groups are now obligated to prepare and maintain special purpose audited financial statements in line with the format, procedures, and rules prescribed by the Federal Tax Authority (FTA).Notably, Clause 3 of Article 2 introduces an unexpected and intriguing provision: Qualifying Free Zone Persons engaged in the distribution of goods or materials in or from a Designated Zone, in accordance with Cabinet Decision No. 265 of 2023, must comply with any additional procedures set by the FTA. The inclusion of this clause - within a decision focused primarily on financial statement requirements - hints that the FTA may be preparing to issue specific compliance obligations targeting Designated Zone distributors.hashtag#CorporateTax hashtag#TaxAdvisory hashtag#QFZP

Η ομάδα του 𝐤𝐚𝐫𝐢𝐞𝐫𝐚.𝐠𝐫 παρευρέθηκε στο Delphi Economic Forum, συμμετέχοντας σε έναν ουσιαστικό διάλογο γύρω από την αγορά εργασίας. Η Manto Patsaoura, 𝐂𝐄𝐎 του Kariera Group, μίλησε ανοιχτά για ένα από τα πιο κρίσιμα ζητήματα της εποχής μας: το 𝐭𝐚𝐥𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐠𝐚𝐩. Στην τοποθέτησή της επεσήμανε:«Η έλλειψη ταλέντων δεν αποτελεί μια βραχυπρόθεσμη πρόκληση, αλλά ένα διαρθρωτικό πρόβλημα που απαιτεί στρατηγική και συντονισμένη δράση. 🚀 A game-changing moment for digital identity — and it starts with ownership.nmbr, Inc., the Dubai-based startup founded by Ahmad Takatkah (أحمد طقاطقه) and officially registered in Delaware, has just opened its public waitlist as of April 14. But this isn’t just another product launch — it’s a movement.The first 1 million users will receive exclusive “nmbrs” — digital identifiers that double as encrypted, user-owned IDs — plus Restricted Common Stock, giving each user real equity in the company.🔐 The mission? Reinvent the phone number into a secure, private, and globally recognized digital identity, fully owned by the individual — not by corporations.This is more than tech. The UAE Ministry of Finance has issued Cabinet Decision No. 84 of 2025, which provides further clarification on the requirements for preparing audited financial statements under the Corporate Tax Law. This new decision replaces Cabinet Decision No. 82 of 2023 and will apply to tax periods beginning on or after 1 January 2025.https://lnkd.in/g6Gawn3J A key update introduced by the new decision is that Tax Groups are now obligated to prepare and maintain special purpose audited financial statements in line with the format, procedures, and rules prescribed by the Federal Tax Authority (FTA).Notably, Clause 3 of Article 2 introduces an unexpected and intriguing provision: Qualifying Free Zone Persons engaged in the distribution of goods or materials in or from a Designated Zone, in accordance with Cabinet Decision No. 265 of 2023, must comply with any additional procedures set by the FTA. The inclusion of this clause - within a decision focused primarily on financial statement requirements - hints that the FTA may be preparing to issue specific compliance obligations targeting Designated Zone distributors.hashtag#CorporateTax hashtag#TaxAdvisory hashtag#QFZP

🇦🇪 Dubai Real Estate is on Fire 🔥 Q1 has just wrapped, and the numbers are speaking loud and clear: Dubai continues to be one of the strongest real estate markets globally — and it’s not slowing down.Here’s a quick breakdown you need to see:💰 AED 142.57 Billion in Property SalesThat’s a 30.3% increase YoY compared to Q1 2024 with a total of 45,381 properties :Apartments : 44% of total sales ( +12.9% vs Q1 2024 )Villas : 33% ( + 55.1% vs Q1 2024 )Land : 21% ( 123.5% vs Q1 2024 ) Commercial : 2% ( +25.3% vs Q1 2024 ) 🏡 Massive Growth in Villas & LandVillas: +55.1%Land: +123.5%Prime communities and waterfront plots are leading the charge — demand is red-hot.📍 Top Performing AreasVillas: Wadi Al Safa 5, Al Yufrah 1, Madinat Al MataarApartments: Business Bay, JVC, Burj KhalifaLand: Palm Jabal Ali, Al Yelayiss 1These zones are seeing unmatched movement — both for end-users and savvy investors.📈 Secondary Market Surging+36.4% YoY in valueThis is a strong signal: people trust completed assets, and liquidity is high.🏦 Mortgages Rising in VolumeAED 41.02B in mortgages with a 27% jump in number of transactions Financing is becoming more accessible — even for premium assets.🎁 Gifting Real Estate — A Dubai SpecialtyAED 9.63B worth of properties were gifted — a unique trend showing legacy planning and generational wealth, especially in Palm Jumeirah and Emirates Living.💎 Luxury is BoomingSome of Q1’s standout deals:AED 140M — Dubai Hills EstateAED 130M — Sobha Hartland 2AED 115M — Palm Jumeirah📊What It MeansDubai is not just about lifestyle anymore — it’s a global value play.With world-class infrastructure, smart regulation, and unmatched ROI potential,now is the time to make your move. 🔑 At SAB Capital, we’re helping investors make strategic decisions — tailored to short-term gains or long-term legacy. If you’re serious about investing in Dubai, let’s connect. 🚀 A game-changing moment for digital identity — and it starts with ownership.nmbr, Inc., the Dubai-based startup founded by Ahmad Takatkah (أحمد طقاطقه) and officially registered in Delaware, has just opened its public waitlist as of April 14. But this isn’t just another product launch — it’s a movement.The first 1 million users will receive exclusive “nmbrs” — digital identifiers that double as encrypted, user-owned IDs — plus Restricted Common Stock, giving each user real equity in the company.🔐 The mission? Reinvent the phone number into a secure, private, and globally recognized digital identity, fully owned by the individual — not by corporations.This is more than tech. It’s a new communication infrastructure built on privacy, community, and shared ownership.💬 “We’re not just building a service — we’re building an ecosystem where users are partners,” says founder Ahmad Takatkah.hashtag#nmbr hashtag#DigitalIdentity hashtag#StartupVision hashtag#PrivacyTech hashtag#EquityForUsers hashtag#DubaiStartups hashtag#TechInnovation hashtag#FutureOfCommunication https://lnkd.in/gbi5tD8Q

The UAE Ministry of Finance has issued Cabinet Decision No. 84 of 2025, which provides further clarification on the requirements for preparing audited financial statements under the Corporate Tax Law. This new decision replaces Cabinet Decision No. 82 of 2023 and will apply to tax periods beginning on or after 1 January 2025.https://lnkd.in/g6Gawn3J A key update introduced by the new decision is that Tax Groups are now obligated to prepare and maintain special purpose audited financial statements in line with the format, procedures, and rules prescribed by the Federal Tax Authority (FTA).Notably, Clause 3 of Article 2 introduces an unexpected and intriguing provision: Qualifying Free Zone Persons engaged in the distribution of goods or materials in or from a Designated Zone, in accordance with Cabinet Decision No. 265 of 2023, must comply with any additional procedures set by the FTA. The inclusion of this clause - within a decision focused primarily on financial statement requirements - hints that the FTA may be preparing to issue specific compliance obligations targeting Designated Zone distributors.hashtag#CorporateTax hashtag#TaxAdvisory hashtag#QFZP

The UAE Ministry of Finance has issued Cabinet Decision No. 84 of 2025, which provides further clarification on the requirements for preparing audited financial statements under the Corporate Tax Law. This new decision replaces Cabinet Decision No. 82 of 2023 and will apply to tax periods beginning on or after 1 January 2025.https://lnkd.in/g6Gawn3J A key update introduced by the new decision is that Tax Groups are now obligated to prepare and maintain special purpose audited financial statements in line with the format, procedures, and rules prescribed by the Federal Tax Authority (FTA).Notably, Clause 3 of Article 2 introduces an unexpected and intriguing provision: Qualifying Free Zone Persons engaged in the distribution of goods or materials in or from a Designated Zone, in accordance with Cabinet Decision No. 265 of 2023, must comply with any additional procedures set by the FTA. The inclusion of this clause - within a decision focused primarily on financial statement requirements - hints that the FTA may be preparing to issue specific compliance obligations targeting Designated Zone distributors.hashtag#CorporateTax hashtag#TaxAdvisory hashtag#QFZP

The UAE Ministry of Finance has issued Cabinet Decision No. 84 of 2025, which provides further clarification on the requirements for preparing audited financial statements under the Corporate Tax Law. This new decision replaces Cabinet Decision No. 82 of 2023 and will apply to tax periods beginning on or after 1 January 2025.https://lnkd.in/g6Gawn3J A key update introduced by the new decision is that Tax Groups are now obligated to prepare and maintain special purpose audited financial statements in line with the format, procedures, and rules prescribed by the Federal Tax Authority (FTA).Notably, Clause 3 of Article 2 introduces an unexpected and intriguing provision: Qualifying Free Zone Persons engaged in the distribution of goods or materials in or from a Designated Zone, in accordance with Cabinet Decision No. 265 of 2023, must comply with any additional procedures set by the FTA. The inclusion of this clause - within a decision focused primarily on financial statement requirements - hints that the FTA may be preparing to issue specific compliance obligations targeting Designated Zone distributors.hashtag#CorporateTax hashtag#TaxAdvisory hashtag#QFZP

Η ομάδα του 𝐤𝐚𝐫𝐢𝐞𝐫𝐚.𝐠𝐫 παρευρέθηκε στο Delphi Economic Forum, συμμετέχοντας σε έναν ουσιαστικό διάλογο γύρω από την αγορά εργασίας. Η Manto Patsaoura, 𝐂𝐄𝐎 του Kariera Group, μίλησε ανοιχτά για ένα από τα πιο κρίσιμα ζητήματα της εποχής μας: το 𝐭𝐚𝐥𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐠𝐚𝐩. Στην τοποθέτησή της επεσήμανε:«Η έλλειψη ταλέντων δεν αποτελεί μια βραχυπρόθεσμη πρόκληση, αλλά ένα διαρθρωτικό πρόβλημα που απαιτεί στρατηγική και συντονισμένη δράση. Δεν αρκεί να αναζητούμε έτοιμους υποψηφίους με τις κατάλληλες δεξιότητες· χρειάζεται να καλλιεργούμε τις δεξιότητες αυτές, δημιουργώντας οικοσυστήματα μάθησης και εξέλιξης, εκεί όπου η εκπαίδευση, η επιχείρηση και η κοινωνία συναντιούνται για να χτίσουν μια νέα γενιά επαγγελματιών. Μόνο έτσι θα δημιουργηθεί ένα ανθρώπινο δυναμικό ανθεκτικό, ευέλικτο και έτοιμο για το μέλλον».hashtag#karieragr hashtag#DelphiEconomicForum hashtag#TalentGap hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#KarieraGroup hashtag#HumanCapital hashtag#WorkforceTransformation

𝗡𝗲𝘄 𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗴𝗿𝗮𝗺 𝗘𝘃𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗗𝗶𝘃𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗥𝗲𝗽𝗼𝗿𝘁 𝗥𝗲𝗹𝗲𝗮𝘀𝗲𝗱: 𝘿𝙚𝙥𝙖𝙧𝙩𝙢𝙚𝙣𝙩 𝙤𝙛 𝙀𝙢𝙥𝙡𝙤𝙮𝙢𝙚𝙣𝙩 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙀𝙘𝙤𝙣𝙤𝙢𝙞𝙘 𝘿𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙡𝙤𝙥𝙢𝙚𝙣𝙩 𝙂𝙧𝙖𝙣𝙩𝙨 𝙈𝙖𝙣𝙖𝙜𝙚𝙢𝙚𝙣𝙩The Office of the Legislative Auditor’s Program Evaluation Division has released the evaluation, 𝘋𝘦𝘱𝘢𝘳𝘵𝘮𝘦𝘯𝘵 𝘰𝘧 𝘌𝘮𝘱𝘭𝘰𝘺𝘮𝘦𝘯𝘵 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘌𝘤𝘰𝘯𝘰𝘮𝘪𝘤 𝘋𝘦𝘷𝘦𝘭𝘰𝘱𝘮𝘦𝘯𝘵 𝘎𝘳𝘢𝘯𝘵𝘴 𝘔𝘢𝘯𝘢𝘨𝘦𝘮𝘦𝘯𝘵.We found that broadband grantees largely met the goals we reviewed. In contrast, the workforce grant programs lack goals, and the performance metrics the Department of Employment and Economic Development (DEED) is statutorily required to report are unhelpful for measuring program success. Further, DEED did not comply with certain state grants management policies. We offered recommendations to DEED and the Legislature to strengthen DEED’s management of grant programs.The full report is now available! Read the findings and information here:🔗 https://lnkd.in/gUyeEXd7𝗨𝗽𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗘𝘃𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻:• 𝘋𝘦𝘱𝘢𝘳𝘵𝘮𝘦𝘯𝘵 𝘰𝘧 𝘕𝘢𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘢𝘭 𝘙𝘦𝘴𝘰𝘶𝘳𝘤𝘦𝘴 𝘓𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘈𝘤𝘲𝘶𝘪𝘴𝘪𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯

🇦🇪 Dubai Real Estate is on Fire 🔥 Q1 has just wrapped, and the numbers are speaking loud and clear: Dubai continues to be one of the strongest real estate markets globally — and it’s not slowing down.Here’s a quick breakdown you need to see:💰 AED 142.57 Billion in Property SalesThat’s a 30.3% increase YoY compared to Q1 2024 with a total of 45,381 properties :Apartments : 44% of total sales ( +12.9% vs Q1 2024 )Villas : 33% ( + 55.1% vs Q1 2024 )Land : 21% ( 123.5% vs Q1 2024 ) Commercial : 2% ( +25.3% vs Q1 2024 ) 🏡 Massive Growth in Villas & LandVillas: +55.1%Land: +123.5%Prime communities and waterfront plots are leading the charge — demand is red-hot.📍 Top Performing AreasVillas: Wadi Al Safa 5, Al Yufrah 1, Madinat Al MataarApartments: Business Bay, JVC, Burj KhalifaLand: Palm Jabal Ali, Al Yelayiss 1These zones are seeing unmatched movement — both for end-users and savvy investors.📈 Secondary Market Surging+36.4% YoY in valueThis is a strong signal: people trust completed assets, and liquidity is high.🏦 Mortgages Rising in VolumeAED 41.02B in mortgages with a 27% jump in number of transactions Financing is becoming more accessible — even for premium assets.🎁 Gifting Real Estate — A Dubai SpecialtyAED 9.63B worth of properties were gifted — a unique trend showing legacy planning and generational wealth, especially in Palm Jumeirah and Emirates Living.💎 Luxury is BoomingSome of Q1’s standout deals:AED 140M — Dubai Hills EstateAED 130M — Sobha Hartland 2AED 115M — Palm Jumeirah📊What It MeansDubai is not just about lifestyle anymore — it’s a global value play.With world-class infrastructure, smart regulation, and unmatched ROI potential,now is the time to make your move. 🔑 At SAB Capital, we’re helping investors make strategic decisions — tailored to short-term gains or long-term legacy. If you’re serious about investing in Dubai, let’s connect. The UAE Ministry of Finance has issued Cabinet Decision No. 84 of 2025, which provides further clarification on the requirements for preparing audited financial statements under the Corporate Tax Law. This new decision replaces Cabinet Decision No. 82 of 2023 and will apply to tax periods beginning on or after 1 January 2025.https://lnkd.in/g6Gawn3J A key update introduced by the new decision is that Tax Groups are now obligated to prepare and maintain special purpose audited financial statements in line with the format, procedures, and rules prescribed by the Federal Tax Authority (FTA).Notably, Clause 3 of Article 2 introduces an unexpected and intriguing provision: Qualifying Free Zone Persons engaged in the distribution of goods or materials in or from a Designated Zone, in accordance with Cabinet Decision No. 265 of 2023, must comply with any additional procedures set by the FTA. The inclusion of this clause - within a decision focused primarily on financial statement requirements - hints that the FTA may be preparing to issue specific compliance obligations targeting Designated Zone distributors.hashtag#CorporateTax hashtag#TaxAdvisory hashtag#QFZP

A New Era for Global Trade?The U.S. tariff crisis isn't just disrupting markets — it's creating a unique opportunity for China to step up as the world’s go-to partner for multilateralism and free trade.At the Annual Investment Meeting Congress in Abu Dhabi, Zayed bin Aweidha, CEO of Abu Dhabi Investment Group (ADIG), shared bold insights:"This isn't just about tariffs. It's about reshaping the global trade order to favor U.S. interests," he said. As panic hit markets and trillions in investor wealth evaporated, Mr. bin Aweidha pointed to China’s strategic advantage — and the Middle East’s crucial role.With the UAE boasting the highest number of sovereign wealth funds globally, new partnerships between China and the region could be key to navigating the storm."This might be the worst crisis yet — and recovery could take 5 to 10 years," he warned. "You can't concentrate global wealth in one place without shaking the entire system."Global leaders are sounding the alarm too. The OECD predicts global GDP growth will slow to 3.1% in 2025, and warns that rising trade barriers could fuel inflation.Sean Doherty from the World Economic Forum called tariffs "an inefficient tool" that only adds uncertainty. His advice? Companies need to diversify fast — and look toward Africa, Latin America, and South Asia for new opportunities.The takeaway: Global trade is evolving fast. The winners will be those who adapt, diversify, and build resilient, future-ready supply chains.hashtag#GlobalTrade hashtag#InvestmentOpportunities hashtag#MiddleEast hashtag#China hashtag#SupplyChainStrategy hashtag#Resilience hashtag#Leadership hashtag#ADIG

"Navigating the Storm: UAE Companies Innovate Amid US Tariff Pressures"While US tariffs present challenges, they also offer some potential benefits for companies in the UAE. One significant advantage is the increased demand for UAE products. With US tariffs making American products more expensive, global buyers may look for alternative suppliers. This opens up opportunities for UAE companies to capture new markets and increase their exports. Additionally, UAE businesses can leverage their strategic location and robust infrastructure to offer competitive pricing and faster delivery times compared to US suppliers.The tariffs also encourage UAE companies to strengthen regional trade. By boosting intra-regional trade, UAE businesses can enhance economic cooperation within the Middle East and with other regions less affected by US tariffs. The UAE's numerous free trade zones provide an attractive environment for businesses to operate with reduced tariffs and customs duties. Companies can use these zones to re-export goods to other markets, potentially bypassing US tariffs.Innovation and efficiency are other areas where UAE businesses can benefit. To remain competitive, companies are investing in new technologies and processes to improve efficiency and reduce costs. This includes adopting digital technologies and enhancing supply chain management. Additionally, businesses are focusing on sustainability to meet regulatory requirements and enhance their reputation. This includes sourcing materials from sustainable suppliers and improving energy efficiency.The UAE's favorable business environment also attracts foreign investment. The uncertainty and high tariffs in the US are causing property investors to reduce their investments there, making UAE real estate more attractive to overseas investors. This can lead to increased demand and higher property values in the UAE. Furthermore, the UAE's business-friendly policies, such as long-term visas and relaxed ownership laws, make it an appealing destination for foreign investors looking to diversify their portfolios.Strategic adjustments by UAE businesses can also mitigate the impact of US tariffs. Companies can export goods to the UAE, which can then be re-exported to the US, potentially avoiding the new US tariffs. The UAE's free zones facilitate this process. Additionally, businesses can assemble or manufacture goods in the UAE using imported components from other countries, helping them avoid higher tariffs on finished products.In conclusion, while US tariffs pose challenges, they also create opportunities for UAE businesses to innovate, diversify, and attract foreign investment. By leveraging their strategic location, investing in technology, and adopting sustainable practices, UAE companies can navigate the uncertainties of the current economic landscape and position themselves for long-term success.

The UAE Ministry of Finance has issued Cabinet Decision No. 84 of 2025, which provides further clarification on the requirements for preparing audited financial statements under the Corporate Tax Law. This new decision replaces Cabinet Decision No. 82 of 2023 and will apply to tax periods beginning on or after 1 January 2025.https://lnkd.in/g6Gawn3J A key update introduced by the new decision is that Tax Groups are now obligated to prepare and maintain special purpose audited financial statements in line with the format, procedures, and rules prescribed by the Federal Tax Authority (FTA).Notably, Clause 3 of Article 2 introduces an unexpected and intriguing provision: Qualifying Free Zone Persons engaged in the distribution of goods or materials in or from a Designated Zone, in accordance with Cabinet Decision No. 265 of 2023, must comply with any additional procedures set by the FTA. The inclusion of this clause - within a decision focused primarily on financial statement requirements - hints that the FTA may be preparing to issue specific compliance obligations targeting Designated Zone distributors.hashtag#CorporateTax hashtag#TaxAdvisory hashtag#QFZP

A New Era for Global Trade?The U.S. tariff crisis isn't just disrupting markets — it's creating a unique opportunity for China to step up as the world’s go-to partner for multilateralism and free trade.At the Annual Investment Meeting Congress in Abu Dhabi, Zayed bin Aweidha, CEO of Abu Dhabi Investment Group (ADIG), shared bold insights:"This isn't just about tariffs. It's about reshaping the global trade order to favor U.S. interests," he said. As panic hit markets and trillions in investor wealth evaporated, Mr. bin Aweidha pointed to China’s strategic advantage — and the Middle East’s crucial role.With the UAE boasting the highest number of sovereign wealth funds globally, new partnerships between China and the region could be key to navigating the storm."This might be the worst crisis yet — and recovery could take 5 to 10 years," he warned. "You can't concentrate global wealth in one place without shaking the entire system."Global leaders are sounding the alarm too. The OECD predicts global GDP growth will slow to 3.1% in 2025, and warns that rising trade barriers could fuel inflation.Sean Doherty from the World Economic Forum called tariffs "an inefficient tool" that only adds uncertainty. His advice? Companies need to diversify fast — and look toward Africa, Latin America, and South Asia for new opportunities.The takeaway: Global trade is evolving fast. The winners will be those who adapt, diversify, and build resilient, future-ready supply chains.hashtag#GlobalTrade hashtag#InvestmentOpportunities hashtag#MiddleEast hashtag#China hashtag#SupplyChainStrategy hashtag#Resilience hashtag#Leadership hashtag#ADIG

"Navigating the Storm: UAE Companies Innovate Amid US Tariff Pressures"While US tariffs present challenges, they also offer some potential benefits for companies in the UAE. One significant advantage is the increased demand for UAE products. With US tariffs making American products more expensive, global buyers may look for alternative suppliers. This opens up opportunities for UAE companies to capture new markets and increase their exports. Additionally, UAE businesses can leverage their strategic location and robust infrastructure to offer competitive pricing and faster delivery times compared to US suppliers.The tariffs also encourage UAE companies to strengthen regional trade. By boosting intra-regional trade, UAE businesses can enhance economic cooperation within the Middle East and with other regions less affected by US tariffs. The UAE's numerous free trade zones provide an attractive environment for businesses to operate with reduced tariffs and customs duties. Companies can use these zones to re-export goods to other markets, potentially bypassing US tariffs.Innovation and efficiency are other areas where UAE businesses can benefit. To remain competitive, companies are investing in new technologies and processes to improve efficiency and reduce costs. This includes adopting digital technologies and enhancing supply chain management. Additionally, businesses are focusing on sustainability to meet regulatory requirements and enhance their reputation. This includes sourcing materials from sustainable suppliers and improving energy efficiency.The UAE's favorable business environment also attracts foreign investment. The uncertainty and high tariffs in the US are causing property investors to reduce their investments there, making UAE real estate more attractive to overseas investors. This can lead to increased demand and higher property values in the UAE. Furthermore, the UAE's business-friendly policies, such as long-term visas and relaxed ownership laws, make it an appealing destination for foreign investors looking to diversify their portfolios.Strategic adjustments by UAE businesses can also mitigate the impact of US tariffs. Companies can export goods to the UAE, which can then be re-exported to the US, potentially avoiding the new US tariffs. The UAE's free zones facilitate this process. Additionally, businesses can assemble or manufacture goods in the UAE using imported components from other countries, helping them avoid higher tariffs on finished products.In conclusion, while US tariffs pose challenges, they also create opportunities for UAE businesses to innovate, diversify, and attract foreign investment. By leveraging their strategic location, investing in technology, and adopting sustainable practices, UAE companies can navigate the uncertainties of the current economic landscape and position themselves for long-term success.

Can tenants sublet rental properties in Dubai?Yes, but you should do it the right way to avoid legal issues down the line. Below is some of the most crucial information you should know if you're looking to rent a property or if your property is on the market for rent.- Subletting in Dubai requires written permission from the landlord.- Tenants must get landlord approval and follow legal procedures before subletting to avoid eviction or disputes.- Unauthorised subletting is a breach of the tenancy contract and can lead to legal action.- Landlords can file a case at the Rental Dispute Settlement Centre if subletting is discovered.- Ejari registration doesn’t protect subtenants unless the subletting is officially approved.Make sure you get professional assistance to make sure you get the best deal in Dubai in the most safe and transparent transfer.Read more: https://lnkd.in/gGEf6Whbhashtag#Dubai hashtag#RealEstate hashtag#Rental hashtag#PropertyMarket

If you’re serious about investing in Dubai, let’s connect. 🚀 A game-changing moment for digital identity — and it starts with ownership.nmbr, Inc., the Dubai-based startup founded by Ahmad Takatkah (أحمد طقاطقه) and officially registered in Delaware, has just opened its public waitlist as of April 14. But this isn’t just another product launch — it’s a movement.The first 1 million users will receive exclusive “nmbrs” — digital identifiers that double as encrypted, user-owned IDs — plus Restricted Common Stock, giving each user real equity in the company.🔐 The mission? Reinvent the phone number into a secure, private, and globally recognized digital identity, fully owned by the individual — not by corporations.This is more than tech. It’s a new communication infrastructure built on privacy, community, and shared ownership.💬 “We’re not just building a service — we’re building an ecosystem where users are partners,” says founder Ahmad Takatkah.hashtag#nmbr hashtag#DigitalIdentity hashtag#StartupVision hashtag#PrivacyTech hashtag#EquityForUsers hashtag#DubaiStartups hashtag#TechInnovation hashtag#FutureOfCommunication https://lnkd.in/gbi5tD8Q

The UAE Ministry of Finance has issued Cabinet Decision No. 84 of 2025, which provides further clarification on the requirements for preparing audited financial statements under the Corporate Tax Law. This new decision replaces Cabinet Decision No. 82 of 2023 and will apply to tax periods beginning on or after 1 January 2025.https://lnkd.in/g6Gawn3J A key update introduced by the new decision is that Tax Groups are now obligated to prepare and maintain special purpose audited financial statements in line with the format, procedures, and rules prescribed by the Federal Tax Authority (FTA).Notably, Clause 3 of Article 2 introduces an unexpected and intriguing provision: Qualifying Free Zone Persons engaged in the distribution of goods or materials in or from a Designated Zone, in accordance with Cabinet Decision No. 265 of 2023, must comply with any additional procedures set by the FTA. The inclusion of this clause - within a decision focused primarily on financial statement requirements - hints that the FTA may be preparing to issue specific compliance obligations targeting Designated Zone distributors.hashtag#CorporateTax hashtag#TaxAdvisory hashtag#QFZP

Η Manto Patsaoura, 𝐂𝐄𝐎 του Kariera Group, μίλησε ανοιχτά για ένα από τα πιο κρίσιμα ζητήματα της εποχής μας: το 𝐭𝐚𝐥𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐠𝐚𝐩. Δεν αρκεί να αναζητούμε έτοιμους υποψηφίους με τις κατάλληλες δεξιότητες· χρειάζεται να καλλιεργούμε τις δεξιότητες αυτές, δημιουργώντας οικοσυστήματα μάθησης και εξέλιξης, εκεί όπου η εκπαίδευση, η επιχείρηση και η κοινωνία συναντιούνται για να χτίσουν μια νέα γενιά επαγγελματιών. A New Era for Global Trade?The U.S. tariff crisis isn't just disrupting markets — it's creating a unique opportunity for China to step up as the world’s go-to partner for multilateralism and free trade.At the Annual Investment Meeting Congress in Abu Dhabi, Zayed bin Aweidha, CEO of Abu Dhabi Investment Group (ADIG), shared bold insights:"This isn't just about tariffs. It's about reshaping the global trade order to favor U.S. interests," he said. As panic hit markets and trillions in investor wealth evaporated, Mr. bin Aweidha pointed to China’s strategic advantage — and the Middle East’s crucial role.With the UAE boasting the highest number of sovereign wealth funds globally, new partnerships between China and the region could be key to navigating the storm."This might be the worst crisis yet — and recovery could take 5 to 10 years," he warned. "You can't concentrate global wealth in one place without shaking the entire system."Global leaders are sounding the alarm too. The OECD predicts global GDP growth will slow to 3.1% in 2025, and warns that rising trade barriers could fuel inflation.Sean Doherty from the World Economic Forum called tariffs "an inefficient tool" that only adds uncertainty. His advice? Companies need to diversify fast — and look toward Africa, Latin America, and South Asia for new opportunities.The takeaway: Global trade is evolving fast. The winners will be those who adapt, diversify, and build resilient, future-ready supply chains.hashtag#GlobalTrade hashtag#InvestmentOpportunities hashtag#MiddleEast hashtag#China hashtag#SupplyChainStrategy hashtag#Resilience hashtag#Leadership hashtag#ADIG

"Navigating the Storm: UAE Companies Innovate Amid US Tariff Pressures"While US tariffs present challenges, they also offer some potential benefits for companies in the UAE. One significant advantage is the increased demand for UAE products. With US tariffs making American products more expensive, global buyers may look for alternative suppliers. This opens up opportunities for UAE companies to capture new markets and increase their exports. Additionally, UAE businesses can leverage their strategic location and robust infrastructure to offer competitive pricing and faster delivery times compared to US suppliers.The tariffs also encourage UAE companies to strengthen regional trade. By boosting intra-regional trade, UAE businesses can enhance economic cooperation within the Middle East and with other regions less affected by US tariffs. The UAE's numerous free trade zones provide an attractive environment for businesses to operate with reduced tariffs and customs duties. Companies can use these zones to re-export goods to other markets, potentially bypassing US tariffs.Innovation and efficiency are other areas where UAE businesses can benefit. To remain competitive, companies are investing in new technologies and processes to improve efficiency and reduce costs. This includes adopting digital technologies and enhancing supply chain management. Additionally, businesses are focusing on sustainability to meet regulatory requirements and enhance their reputation. This includes sourcing materials from sustainable suppliers and improving energy efficiency.The UAE's favorable business environment also attracts foreign investment. The uncertainty and high tariffs in the US are causing property investors to reduce their investments there, making UAE real estate more attractive to overseas investors. This can lead to increased demand and higher property values in the UAE. Furthermore, the UAE's business-friendly policies, such as long-term visas and relaxed ownership laws, make it an appealing destination for foreign investors looking to diversify their portfolios.Strategic adjustments by UAE businesses can also mitigate the impact of US tariffs. Companies can export goods to the UAE, which can then be re-exported to the US, potentially avoiding the new US tariffs. The UAE's free zones facilitate this process. Additionally, businesses can assemble or manufacture goods in the UAE using imported components from other countries, helping them avoid higher tariffs on finished products.In conclusion, while US tariffs pose challenges, they also create opportunities for UAE businesses to innovate, diversify, and attract foreign investment. By leveraging their strategic location, investing in technology, and adopting sustainable practices, UAE companies can navigate the uncertainties of the current economic landscape and position themselves for long-term success.

Can tenants sublet rental properties in Dubai?Yes, but you should do it the right way to avoid legal issues down the line. Below is some of the most crucial information you should know if you're looking to rent a property or if your property is on the market for rent.- Subletting in Dubai requires written permission from the landlord.- Tenants must get landlord approval and follow legal procedures before subletting to avoid eviction or disputes.- Unauthorised subletting is a breach of the tenancy contract and can lead to legal action.- Landlords can file a case at the Rental Dispute Settlement Centre if subletting is discovered.- Ejari registration doesn’t protect subtenants unless the subletting is officially approved.Make sure you get professional assistance to make sure you get the best deal in Dubai in the most safe and transparent transfer.Read more: https://lnkd.in/gGEf6Whbhashtag#Dubai hashtag#RealEstate hashtag#Rental hashtag#PropertyMarket

The UAE Ministry of Finance has issued Cabinet Decision No. 84 of 2025, which provides further clarification on the requirements for preparing audited financial statements under the Corporate Tax Law. This new decision replaces Cabinet Decision No. 82 of 2023 and will apply to tax periods beginning on or after 1 January 2025.https://lnkd.in/g6Gawn3J A key update introduced by the new decision is that Tax Groups are now obligated to prepare and maintain special purpose audited financial statements in line with the format, procedures, and rules prescribed by the Federal Tax Authority (FTA).Notably, Clause 3 of Article 2 introduces an unexpected and intriguing provision: Qualifying Free Zone Persons engaged in the distribution of goods or materials in or from a Designated Zone, in accordance with Cabinet Decision No. 265 of 2023, must comply with any additional procedures set by the FTA. The inclusion of this clause - within a decision focused primarily on financial statement requirements - hints that the FTA may be preparing to issue specific compliance obligations targeting Designated Zone distributors.hashtag#CorporateTax hashtag#TaxAdvisory hashtag#QFZP

A New Era for Global Trade?The U.S. tariff crisis isn't just disrupting markets — it's creating a unique opportunity for China to step up as the world’s go-to partner for multilateralism and free trade.At the Annual Investment Meeting Congress in Abu Dhabi, Zayed bin Aweidha, CEO of Abu Dhabi Investment Group (ADIG), shared bold insights:"This isn't just about tariffs. It's about reshaping the global trade order to favor U.S. interests," he said. As panic hit markets and trillions in investor wealth evaporated, Mr. bin Aweidha pointed to China’s strategic advantage — and the Middle East’s crucial role.With the UAE boasting the highest number of sovereign wealth funds globally, new partnerships between China and the region could be key to navigating the storm."This might be the worst crisis yet — and recovery could take 5 to 10 years," he warned. "You can't concentrate global wealth in one place without shaking the entire system."Global leaders are sounding the alarm too. The OECD predicts global GDP growth will slow to 3.1% in 2025, and warns that rising trade barriers could fuel inflation.Sean Doherty from the World Economic Forum called tariffs "an inefficient tool" that only adds uncertainty. His advice? Companies need to diversify fast — and look toward Africa, Latin America, and South Asia for new opportunities.The takeaway: Global trade is evolving fast. The winners will be those who adapt, diversify, and build resilient, future-ready supply chains.hashtag#GlobalTrade hashtag#InvestmentOpportunities hashtag#MiddleEast hashtag#China hashtag#SupplyChainStrategy hashtag#Resilience hashtag#Leadership hashtag#ADIG

"Navigating the Storm: UAE Companies Innovate Amid US Tariff Pressures"While US tariffs present challenges, they also offer some potential benefits for companies in the UAE. One significant advantage is the increased demand for UAE products. With US tariffs making American products more expensive, global buyers may look for alternative suppliers. This opens up opportunities for UAE companies to capture new markets and increase their exports. Additionally, UAE businesses can leverage their strategic location and robust infrastructure to offer competitive pricing and faster delivery times compared to US suppliers.The tariffs also encourage UAE companies to strengthen regional trade. By boosting intra-regional trade, UAE businesses can enhance economic cooperation within the Middle East and with other regions less affected by US tariffs. The UAE's numerous free trade zones provide an attractive environment for businesses to operate with reduced tariffs and customs duties. Companies can use these zones to re-export goods to other markets, potentially bypassing US tariffs.Innovation and efficiency are other areas where UAE businesses can benefit. To remain competitive, companies are investing in new technologies and processes to improve efficiency and reduce costs. This includes adopting digital technologies and enhancing supply chain management. Additionally, businesses are focusing on sustainability to meet regulatory requirements and enhance their reputation. This includes sourcing materials from sustainable suppliers and improving energy efficiency.The UAE's favorable business environment also attracts foreign investment. The uncertainty and high tariffs in the US are causing property investors to reduce their investments there, making UAE real estate more attractive to overseas investors. This can lead to increased demand and higher property values in the UAE. Furthermore, the UAE's business-friendly policies, such as long-term visas and relaxed ownership laws, make it an appealing destination for foreign investors looking to diversify their portfolios.Strategic adjustments by UAE businesses can also mitigate the impact of US tariffs. Companies can export goods to the UAE, which can then be re-exported to the US, potentially avoiding the new US tariffs. The UAE's free zones facilitate this process. Additionally, businesses can assemble or manufacture goods in the UAE using imported components from other countries, helping them avoid higher tariffs on finished products.In conclusion, while US tariffs pose challenges, they also create opportunities for UAE businesses to innovate, diversify, and attract foreign investment. By leveraging their strategic location, investing in technology, and adopting sustainable practices, UAE companies can navigate the uncertainties of the current economic landscape and position themselves for long-term success.

The UAE Ministry of Finance has issued Cabinet Decision No. 84 of 2025, which provides further clarification on the requirements for preparing audited financial statements under the Corporate Tax Law. This new decision replaces Cabinet Decision No. 82 of 2023 and will apply to tax periods beginning on or after 1 January 2025.https://lnkd.in/g6Gawn3J A key update introduced by the new decision is that Tax Groups are now obligated to prepare and maintain special purpose audited financial statements in line with the format, procedures, and rules prescribed by the Federal Tax Authority (FTA).Notably, Clause 3 of Article 2 introduces an unexpected and intriguing provision: Qualifying Free Zone Persons engaged in the distribution of goods or materials in or from a Designated Zone, in accordance with Cabinet Decision No. 265 of 2023, must comply with any additional procedures set by the FTA. The inclusion of this clause - within a decision focused primarily on financial statement requirements - hints that the FTA may be preparing to issue specific compliance obligations targeting Designated Zone distributors.hashtag#CorporateTax hashtag#TaxAdvisory hashtag#QFZP

A New Era for Global Trade?The U.S. tariff crisis isn't just disrupting markets — it's creating a unique opportunity for China to step up as the world’s go-to partner for multilateralism and free trade.At the Annual Investment Meeting Congress in Abu Dhabi, Zayed bin Aweidha, CEO of Abu Dhabi Investment Group (ADIG), shared bold insights:"This isn't just about tariffs. It's about reshaping the global trade order to favor U.S. interests," he said. As panic hit markets and trillions in investor wealth evaporated, Mr. bin Aweidha pointed to China’s strategic advantage — and the Middle East’s crucial role.With the UAE boasting the highest number of sovereign wealth funds globally, new partnerships between China and the region could be key to navigating the storm."This might be the worst crisis yet — and recovery could take 5 to 10 years," he warned. "You can't concentrate global wealth in one place without shaking the entire system."Global leaders are sounding the alarm too. The OECD predicts global GDP growth will slow to 3.1% in 2025, and warns that rising trade barriers could fuel inflation.Sean Doherty from the World Economic Forum called tariffs "an inefficient tool" that only adds uncertainty. His advice? Companies need to diversify fast — and look toward Africa, Latin America, and South Asia for new opportunities.The takeaway: Global trade is evolving fast. The winners will be those who adapt, diversify, and build resilient, future-ready supply chains.hashtag#GlobalTrade hashtag#InvestmentOpportunities hashtag#MiddleEast hashtag#China hashtag#SupplyChainStrategy hashtag#Resilience hashtag#Leadership hashtag#ADIG

"Navigating the Storm: UAE Companies Innovate Amid US Tariff Pressures"While US tariffs present challenges, they also offer some potential benefits for companies in the UAE. One significant advantage is the increased demand for UAE products. With US tariffs making American products more expensive, global buyers may look for alternative suppliers. This opens up opportunities for UAE companies to capture new markets and increase their exports. Additionally, UAE businesses can leverage their strategic location and robust infrastructure to offer competitive pricing and faster delivery times compared to US suppliers.The tariffs also encourage UAE companies to strengthen regional trade. By boosting intra-regional trade, UAE businesses can enhance economic cooperation within the Middle East and with other regions less affected by US tariffs. The UAE's numerous free trade zones provide an attractive environment for businesses to operate with reduced tariffs and customs duties. Companies can use these zones to re-export goods to other markets, potentially bypassing US tariffs.Innovation and efficiency are other areas where UAE businesses can benefit. To remain competitive, companies are investing in new technologies and processes to improve efficiency and reduce costs. This includes adopting digital technologies and enhancing supply chain management. Additionally, businesses are focusing on sustainability to meet regulatory requirements and enhance their reputation. This includes sourcing materials from sustainable suppliers and improving energy efficiency.The UAE's favorable business environment also attracts foreign investment. The uncertainty and high tariffs in the US are causing property investors to reduce their investments there, making UAE real estate more attractive to overseas investors. This can lead to increased demand and higher property values in the UAE. Furthermore, the UAE's business-friendly policies, such as long-term visas and relaxed ownership laws, make it an appealing destination for foreign investors looking to diversify their portfolios.Strategic adjustments by UAE businesses can also mitigate the impact of US tariffs. Companies can export goods to the UAE, which can then be re-exported to the US, potentially avoiding the new US tariffs. The UAE's free zones facilitate this process. Additionally, businesses can assemble or manufacture goods in the UAE using imported components from other countries, helping them avoid higher tariffs on finished products.In conclusion, while US tariffs pose challenges, they also create opportunities for UAE businesses to innovate, diversify, and attract foreign investment. By leveraging their strategic location, investing in technology, and adopting sustainable practices, UAE companies can navigate the uncertainties of the current economic landscape and position themselves for long-term success.

The UAE Ministry of Finance has issued Cabinet Decision No. 84 of 2025, which provides further clarification on the requirements for preparing audited financial statements under the Corporate Tax Law. This new decision replaces Cabinet Decision No. 82 of 2023 and will apply to tax periods beginning on or after 1 January 2025.https://lnkd.in/g6Gawn3J A key update introduced by the new decision is that Tax Groups are now obligated to prepare and maintain special purpose audited financial statements in line with the format, procedures, and rules prescribed by the Federal Tax Authority (FTA).Notably, Clause 3 of Article 2 introduces an unexpected and intriguing provision: Qualifying Free Zone Persons engaged in the distribution of goods or materials in or from a Designated Zone, in accordance with Cabinet Decision No. 265 of 2023, must comply with any additional procedures set by the FTA. The inclusion of this clause - within a decision focused primarily on financial statement requirements - hints that the FTA may be preparing to issue specific compliance obligations targeting Designated Zone distributors.hashtag#CorporateTax hashtag#TaxAdvisory hashtag#QFZP

A New Era for Global Trade?The U.S. tariff crisis isn't just disrupting markets — it's creating a unique opportunity for China to step up as the world’s go-to partner for multilateralism and free trade.At the Annual Investment Meeting Congress in Abu Dhabi, Zayed bin Aweidha, CEO of Abu Dhabi Investment Group (ADIG), shared bold insights:"This isn't just about tariffs. It's about reshaping the global trade order to favor U.S. interests," he said. As panic hit markets and trillions in investor wealth evaporated, Mr. bin Aweidha pointed to China’s strategic advantage — and the Middle East’s crucial role.With the UAE boasting the highest number of sovereign wealth funds globally, new partnerships between China and the region could be key to navigating the storm."This might be the worst crisis yet — and recovery could take 5 to 10 years," he warned. "You can't concentrate global wealth in one place without shaking the entire system."Global leaders are sounding the alarm too. The OECD predicts global GDP growth will slow to 3.1% in 2025, and warns that rising trade barriers could fuel inflation.Sean Doherty from the World Economic Forum called tariffs "an inefficient tool" that only adds uncertainty. His advice? Companies need to diversify fast — and look toward Africa, Latin America, and South Asia for new opportunities.The takeaway: Global trade is evolving fast. The winners will be those who adapt, diversify, and build resilient, future-ready supply chains.hashtag#GlobalTrade hashtag#InvestmentOpportunities hashtag#MiddleEast hashtag#China hashtag#SupplyChainStrategy hashtag#Resilience hashtag#Leadership hashtag#ADIG

"Navigating the Storm: UAE Companies Innovate Amid US Tariff Pressures"While US tariffs present challenges, they also offer some potential benefits for companies in the UAE. One significant advantage is the increased demand for UAE products. With US tariffs making American products more expensive, global buyers may look for alternative suppliers. This opens up opportunities for UAE companies to capture new markets and increase their exports. Additionally, UAE businesses can leverage their strategic location and robust infrastructure to offer competitive pricing and faster delivery times compared to US suppliers.The tariffs also encourage UAE companies to strengthen regional trade. By boosting intra-regional trade, UAE businesses can enhance economic cooperation within the Middle East and with other regions less affected by US tariffs. The UAE's numerous free trade zones provide an attractive environment for businesses to operate with reduced tariffs and customs duties. Companies can use these zones to re-export goods to other markets, potentially bypassing US tariffs.Innovation and efficiency are other areas where UAE businesses can benefit. To remain competitive, companies are investing in new technologies and processes to improve efficiency and reduce costs. This includes adopting digital technologies and enhancing supply chain management. Additionally, businesses are focusing on sustainability to meet regulatory requirements and enhance their reputation. This includes sourcing materials from sustainable suppliers and improving energy efficiency.The UAE's favorable business environment also attracts foreign investment. The uncertainty and high tariffs in the US are causing property investors to reduce their investments there, making UAE real estate more attractive to overseas investors. This can lead to increased demand and higher property values in the UAE. Furthermore, the UAE's business-friendly policies, such as long-term visas and relaxed ownership laws, make it an appealing destination for foreign investors looking to diversify their portfolios.Strategic adjustments by UAE businesses can also mitigate the impact of US tariffs. Companies can export goods to the UAE, which can then be re-exported to the US, potentially avoiding the new US tariffs. The UAE's free zones facilitate this process. Additionally, businesses can assemble or manufacture goods in the UAE using imported components from other countries, helping them avoid higher tariffs on finished products.In conclusion, while US tariffs pose challenges, they also create opportunities for UAE businesses to innovate, diversify, and attract foreign investment. By leveraging their strategic location, investing in technology, and adopting sustainable practices, UAE companies can navigate the uncertainties of the current economic landscape and position themselves for long-term success.

Can tenants sublet rental properties in Dubai?Yes, but you should do it the right way to avoid legal issues down the line. Below is some of the most crucial information you should know if you're looking to rent a property or if your property is on the market for rent.- Subletting in Dubai requires written permission from the landlord.- Tenants must get landlord approval and follow legal procedures before subletting to avoid eviction or disputes.- Unauthorised subletting is a breach of the tenancy contract and can lead to legal action.- Landlords can file a case at the Rental Dispute Settlement Centre if subletting is discovered.- Ejari registration doesn’t protect subtenants unless the subletting is officially approved.Make sure you get professional assistance to make sure you get the best deal in Dubai in the most safe and transparent transfer.Read more: https://lnkd.in/gGEf6Whbhashtag#Dubai hashtag#RealEstate hashtag#Rental hashtag#PropertyMarket

The UAE Ministry of Finance has issued Cabinet Decision No. 84 of 2025, which provides further clarification on the requirements for preparing audited financial statements under the Corporate Tax Law. This new decision replaces Cabinet Decision No. 82 of 2023 and will apply to tax periods beginning on or after 1 January 2025.https://lnkd.in/g6Gawn3J A key update introduced by the new decision is that Tax Groups are now obligated to prepare and maintain special purpose audited financial statements in line with the format, procedures, and rules prescribed by the Federal Tax Authority (FTA).Notably, Clause 3 of Article 2 introduces an unexpected and intriguing provision: Qualifying Free Zone Persons engaged in the distribution of goods or materials in or from a Designated Zone, in accordance with Cabinet Decision No. 265 of 2023, must comply with any additional procedures set by the FTA. The inclusion of this clause - within a decision focused primarily on financial statement requirements - hints that the FTA may be preparing to issue specific compliance obligations targeting Designated Zone distributors.hashtag#CorporateTax hashtag#TaxAdvisory hashtag#QFZP

A New Era for Global Trade?The U.S. tariff crisis isn't just disrupting markets — it's creating a unique opportunity for China to step up as the world’s go-to partner for multilateralism and free trade.At the Annual Investment Meeting Congress in Abu Dhabi, Zayed bin Aweidha, CEO of Abu Dhabi Investment Group (ADIG), shared bold insights:"This isn't just about tariffs. It's about reshaping the global trade order to favor U.S. interests," he said. As panic hit markets and trillions in investor wealth evaporated, Mr. bin Aweidha pointed to China’s strategic advantage — and the Middle East’s crucial role.With the UAE boasting the highest number of sovereign wealth funds globally, new partnerships between China and the region could be key to navigating the storm."This might be the worst crisis yet — and recovery could take 5 to 10 years," he warned. "You can't concentrate global wealth in one place without shaking the entire system."Global leaders are sounding the alarm too. The OECD predicts global GDP growth will slow to 3.1% in 2025, and warns that rising trade barriers could fuel inflation.Sean Doherty from the World Economic Forum called tariffs "an inefficient tool" that only adds uncertainty. His advice? Companies need to diversify fast — and look toward Africa, Latin America, and South Asia for new opportunities.The takeaway: Global trade is evolving fast. The winners will be those who adapt, diversify, and build resilient, future-ready supply chains.hashtag#GlobalTrade hashtag#InvestmentOpportunities hashtag#MiddleEast hashtag#China hashtag#SupplyChainStrategy hashtag#Resilience hashtag#Leadership hashtag#ADIG

"Navigating the Storm: UAE Companies Innovate Amid US Tariff Pressures"While US tariffs present challenges, they also offer some potential benefits for companies in the UAE. One significant advantage is the increased demand for UAE products. With US tariffs making American products more expensive, global buyers may look for alternative suppliers. This opens up opportunities for UAE companies to capture new markets and increase their exports. Additionally, UAE businesses can leverage their strategic location and robust infrastructure to offer competitive pricing and faster delivery times compared to US suppliers.The tariffs also encourage UAE companies to strengthen regional trade. By boosting intra-regional trade, UAE businesses can enhance economic cooperation within the Middle East and with other regions less affected by US tariffs. The UAE's numerous free trade zones provide an attractive environment for businesses to operate with reduced tariffs and customs duties. Companies can use these zones to re-export goods to other markets, potentially bypassing US tariffs.Innovation and efficiency are other areas where UAE businesses can benefit. To remain competitive, companies are investing in new technologies and processes to improve efficiency and reduce costs. This includes adopting digital technologies and enhancing supply chain management. Additionally, businesses are focusing on sustainability to meet regulatory requirements and enhance their reputation. This includes sourcing materials from sustainable suppliers and improving energy efficiency.The UAE's favorable business environment also attracts foreign investment. The uncertainty and high tariffs in the US are causing property investors to reduce their investments there, making UAE real estate more attractive to overseas investors. This can lead to increased demand and higher property values in the UAE. Furthermore, the UAE's business-friendly policies, such as long-term visas and relaxed ownership laws, make it an appealing destination for foreign investors looking to diversify their portfolios.Strategic adjustments by UAE businesses can also mitigate the impact of US tariffs. Companies can export goods to the UAE, which can then be re-exported to the US, potentially avoiding the new US tariffs. The UAE's free zones facilitate this process. Additionally, businesses can assemble or manufacture goods in the UAE using imported components from other countries, helping them avoid higher tariffs on finished products.In conclusion, while US tariffs pose challenges, they also create opportunities for UAE businesses to innovate, diversify, and attract foreign investment. By leveraging their strategic location, investing in technology, and adopting sustainable practices, UAE companies can navigate the uncertainties of the current economic landscape and position themselves for long-term success.

Can tenants sublet rental properties in Dubai?Yes, but you should do it the right way to avoid legal issues down the line. Below is some of the most crucial information you should know if you're looking to rent a property or if your property is on the market for rent.- Subletting in Dubai requires written permission from the landlord.- Tenants must get landlord approval and follow legal procedures before subletting to avoid eviction or disputes.- Unauthorised subletting is a breach of the tenancy contract and can lead to legal action.- Landlords can file a case at the Rental Dispute Settlement Centre if subletting is discovered.- Ejari registration doesn’t protect subtenants unless the subletting is officially approved.Make sure you get professional assistance to make sure you get the best deal in Dubai in the most safe and transparent transfer.Read more: https://lnkd.in/gGEf6Whbhashtag#Dubai hashtag#RealEstate hashtag#Rental hashtag#PropertyMarket

The UAE Ministry of Finance has issued Cabinet Decision No. 84 of 2025, which provides further clarification on the requirements for preparing audited financial statements under the Corporate Tax Law. This new decision replaces Cabinet Decision No. 82 of 2023 and will apply to tax periods beginning on or after 1 January 2025.https://lnkd.in/g6Gawn3J A key update introduced by the new decision is that Tax Groups are now obligated to prepare and maintain special purpose audited financial statements in line with the format, procedures, and rules prescribed by the Federal Tax Authority (FTA).Notably, Clause 3 of Article 2 introduces an unexpected and intriguing provision: Qualifying Free Zone Persons engaged in the distribution of goods or materials in or from a Designated Zone, in accordance with Cabinet Decision No. 265 of 2023, must comply with any additional procedures set by the FTA. The inclusion of this clause - within a decision focused primarily on financial statement requirements - hints that the FTA may be preparing to issue specific compliance obligations targeting Designated Zone distributors.hashtag#CorporateTax hashtag#TaxAdvisory hashtag#QFZP
